column4: how does sudo improve security ? everybody knows about it and if they can get an admin account what denies them sudo access ? would it not be easyer to use a root account name people cannot guess ?
you have to be in the right group to use it, you also need to take extra steps to do admin things
you also are running the desktop and other apps as user so only apps yu run using sudo and gksudo are ran with elevated priveledges so makes your system more secure
root is common to all *nix boxes, if the account is disabled then their is a 0% chance of the account being captured
if it has a password this is increased and also programs running as root may be captured and their access used. If this is user then the access is drastically reduced
so runnig irc clients and web browsers is hugely foolhardy
then use   sudo -i     while you edit stuff
you can exit / quit the sudo -i once you are done
once the system is up and running, sudo is rarely needed
